{
  "title": "GitHub · Build and ship software on a single, collaborative platform",
  "author": null,

  "id": null,
  "license": null,

  "text": "Build and ship software on a single, collaborative platform.
Join the world’s most widely adopted AI-powered developer platform.
GitHub features.
Code quickly and more securely with GitHub Copilot embedded throughout your workflows.
GitHub customers.
Accelerate performance.
With GitHub Copilot embedded throughout the platform, you can simplify your toolchain, automate tasks, and improve the developer experience.
Work 55% faster. Increase productivity with AI-powered coding assistance, including code completion, chat, and more.
Duolingo boosts developer speed by 25% with GitHub Copilot.
[Read customer story](https://github.com/customer-stories/duolingo)
2024 Gartner® Magic Quadrant™ for AI Code Assistants.
[Read industry report](https://www.gartner.com/doc/reprints?id=1-2IKO4MPE&ct=240819&st=sb)
Built-in application security where found means fixed.
Use AI to find and fix vulnerabilities—freeing your teams to ship more secure software faster.
Apply fixes in seconds. Spend less time fixing vulnerabilities and more time building features with Copilot Autofix.
Solve security debt. Leverage AI-assisted security campaigns to reduce application vulnerabilities and zero-day attacks.
[Discover security campaigns](https://github.com/security/advanced-security)
Dependencies you can depend on. Update vulnerable dependencies with supported fixes for breaking changes.
[Learn about Dependabot](https://github.com/security/advanced-security/software-supply-chain)
Your secrets, your business: protected. Detect, prevent, and remediate leaked secrets across your organization.
[Read about secret scanning](https://github.com/security/advanced-security/secret-protection)
7x faster vulnerability fixes with GitHub.
90% coverage of alert types in [all supported languages with Copilot Autofix](https://docs.github.com/code-security/code-scanning/introduction-to-code-scanning/about-code-scanning-with-codeql#about-codeql)
Work together, achieve more.
Collaborate with your teams, use management tools that sync with your projects, and code from anywhere—all on a single, integrated platform.
Your workflows, your way. Plan effectively with an adaptable spreadsheet that syncs with your work.
From startups to enterprises, GitHub scales with teams of any size in any industry.
Millions of developers and businesses call GitHub home.
Whether you’re scaling your development process or just learning how to code, GitHub is where you belong. Join the world’s most widely adopted AI-powered developer platform to build the technologies that redefine what’s possible.",
  "language": "en",

[Read industry report](https://www.gartner.com/doc/reprints?id=1-2IKO4MPE&ct=240819&st=sb)

7x faster vulnerability fixes with GitHub

From startups to enterprises, GitHub scales with teams of any size in any industry.
Millions of developers and businesses call GitHub home
Whether you’re scaling your development process or just learning how to code, GitHub is where you belong. Join the world’s most widely adopted AI-powered developer platform to build the technologies that redefine what’s possible."

|\n|\n|---|---|\n| Site web | |\n| Distinctions | Liste d\u00e9taill\u00e9e\nPravasi Bharatiya Samman (\n|\nSatya Narayana Nadella (en [t\u00e9lougou](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/T%C3%A9lougou) \u0c38\u0c24\u0c4d\u0c2f \u0c28\u0c3e\u0c26\u0c46\u0c33\u0c4d\u0c32), n\u00e9 le \u00e0 [Hyderabad](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad), en [Inde](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inde), est le [pr\u00e9sident-directeur g\u00e9n\u00e9ral](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pr%C3%A9sident-directeur_g%C3%A9n%C3%A9ral) (PDG) de [Microsoft](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft) [1].\nIl \u00e9tait pr\u00e9c\u00e9demment vice-pr\u00e9sident de la branche \u00ab Cloud et Entreprise \u00bb de cette entreprise, notamment responsable de la gestion et de l'\u00e9volution des plates-formes informatiques (serveurs et postes de travail) de la branche \u00ab D\u00e9veloppement \u00bb et des activit\u00e9s \u00ab Cloud \u00bb (activit\u00e9s d\u00e9mat\u00e9rialis\u00e9es) du groupe.\nIl dispose de la citoyennet\u00e9 am\u00e9ricaine [2].\nJeunesse et \u00e9tudes\n[[modifier](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&veaction=edit\u00a7ion=1)|\n[modifier le code](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&action=edit\u00a7ion=1)]\nSatya Nadella est n\u00e9 \u00e0 Hyderabad, dans l'[\u00c9tat indien](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89tats_et_territoires_de_l%27Inde) de l'[Andhra Pradesh](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh), dans une famille [hindoue](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindoue) parlant le [t\u00e9lougou](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/T%C3%A9lougou)[[3]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-3),[[4]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-4), [5]. Sa m\u00e8re, Prabhavati Yugandhar, \u00e9tait conf\u00e9renci\u00e8re en\n[sanskrit](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanskrit)\nau\n[[6]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-6)[Sri Padmavathi College](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sri_Padmavati_Mahila_Visvavidyalayam&action=edit&redlink=1)\n[(en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Padmavati_Mahila_Visvavidyalayam)de\n[Tirupati](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tirupati)\net son p\u00e8re, Bukkapuram Nadella Yugandhar, \u00e9tait fonctionnaire au sein de la\n[[7]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-NadellaFamily-7)[fonction publique administrative indienne](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fonction_publique_en_Inde)(l'IAS) et a servi en tant que secr\u00e9taire des anciens\n[premiers ministres indiens](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premier_ministre_de_l%27Inde)\n[Narasimha Rao](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pamulaparthi_Venkata_Narasimha_Rao)et\n[Manmohan Singh](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manmohan_Singh)\n[[8]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-8),\n.\n[[9]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-9)Il \u00e9tudie \u00e0 la [Hyderabad Public School](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hyderabad_Public_School&action=edit&redlink=1) [(en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad_Public_School) [10] avant d'int\u00e9grer la Manipal Institute of Technology\n\u2013 de la\n[[11]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-11)[Manipal Academy of Higher Education](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Manipal_Academy_of_Higher_Education&action=edit&redlink=1)\n[(en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manipal_Academy_of_Higher_Education)\u2013 et d'obtenir un dipl\u00f4me d'ing\u00e9nierie en \u00e9lectronique et communication\n[[12]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-12),\n.\n[[13]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-13)Apr\u00e8s s'\u00eatre [expatri\u00e9](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expatri%C3%A9) aux [\u00c9tats-Unis](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89tats-Unis), Nadella obtient un [master](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master_(grade_universitaire)) en sciences informatiques \u00e0 l'[universit\u00e9 du Wisconsin \u00e0 Milwaukee](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universit%C3%A9_du_Wisconsin_%C3%A0_Milwaukee)[[14]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-14), [15], ainsi qu'un\n[MBA](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ma%C3%AEtrise_en_administration_des_affaires)\u00e0 l'\n[universit\u00e9 de Chicago](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universit%C3%A9_de_Chicago)\n.\n[[16]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-16)Carri\u00e8re\n[[modifier](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&veaction=edit\u00a7ion=2)|\n[modifier le code](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&action=edit\u00a7ion=2)]\nSun Microsystems\n[[modifier](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&veaction=edit\u00a7ion=3)|\n[modifier le code](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&action=edit\u00a7ion=3)]\nNadella travaille pour [Sun Microsystems](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun_Microsystems) [17] en tant qu'ing\u00e9nieur technique, avant de rejoindre le groupe\n[Microsoft](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft)en\n[1992](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/1992).\nMicrosoft\n[[modifier](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&veaction=edit\u00a7ion=4)|\n[modifier le code](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&action=edit\u00a7ion=4)]\n1992\u20132014\n[[modifier](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&veaction=edit\u00a7ion=5)|\n[modifier le code](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&action=edit\u00a7ion=5)]\nEn 1992, Nadella rejoint Microsoft et fait partie de la trentaine d'immigrants indiens travaillant pour la soci\u00e9t\u00e9. Il a notamment travaill\u00e9 sur le projet de t\u00e9l\u00e9vision interactive de Microsoft [18] (MSN TV) et le syst\u00e8me d\u2019exploitation\n[Windows NT](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_NT)\n.\n[[17]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-The_rise_of_Satya_Nadella,_the_CEO_who_totally_turned_Microsoft_around_in_5_years_and_made_it_more_valuable_than_Apple-17)Chez Microsoft, il occupa notamment les postes de vice-pr\u00e9sident senior du d\u00e9partement \u00ab [Recherche & D\u00e9veloppement](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recherche_et_d%C3%A9veloppement) \u00bb de la division \u00ab Services en ligne \u00bb (Online Services) et le poste de vice-pr\u00e9sident de la division \u00ab Business \u00bb de Microsoft. Plus tard, il fut nomm\u00e9 pr\u00e9sident de la division \u00ab Business serveurs et outils \u00bb (19 milliards de dollars de [chiffre d'affaires](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiffre_d%27affaires)), et dirigea la transformation du mod\u00e8le \u00e9conomique et de l'organisation des ressources internes de la branche \u00ab Services client \u00bb vers les branches \u00ab [Cloud computing](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing) \u00bb et \u00ab Cloud services \u00bb. Il fut notamment l'artisan de l'int\u00e9gration de [Microsoft SQL Server](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_SQL_Server), de [Windows Server](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Server) et de la branche \u00ab D\u00e9veloppement \u00bb (autour de [Microsoft Visual Studio](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Visual_Studio)) dans la solution [cloud](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_(syst%C3%A8me_d%27exploitation)) [Windows Azure](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Azure). Ainsi, les revenus de la division \u00ab Cloud services \u00bb sont pass\u00e9s de 16,6 milliards de dollars en 2011 \u00e0 plus de 20 milliards de dollars en 2013 [19].\nEn tant que PDG (2014\u2013)\n[[modifier](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&veaction=edit\u00a7ion=6)|\n[modifier le code](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&action=edit\u00a7ion=6)]\nDepuis le , Satya Nadella est le nouveau PDG de Microsoft et succ\u00e8de \u00e0 [Steve Ballmer](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Ballmer) [20]. Depuis le d\u00e9but de son mandat il s\u2019attelle au changement de la culture d'entreprise de Microsoft et \u00e0 la simplification du processus d\u2019ing\u00e9nierie, pour \u00eatre plus r\u00e9actif sur le secteur\n.\n[[21]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-21)En , il annonce la suppression d'environ 14 % des effectifs de Microsoft d'ici \u00e0 2015, soit 18 000 postes, cela afin d'adapter la taille de l'entreprise face aux deux leaders du secteur que sont [Google](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google) et [Apple](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple) [22].\nLe , Microsoft annonce l'int\u00e9gration du [bitcoin](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin), monnaie cryptographique en plein essor de popularit\u00e9, \u00e0 sa plateforme [Xbox](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_(console)). Il est \u00e9galement annonc\u00e9 que Microsoft continuera de surveiller attentivement l'\u00e9volution du bitcoin, dans le but de l'int\u00e9grer \u00e0 d'autres projets futurs. En conf\u00e9rence de presse, Satya Nadella affirme \u00eatre tr\u00e8s int\u00e9ress\u00e9 par la technologie [Blockchain](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blockchain) [23].\nIl mise \u00e9galement sur le Cloud et a particip\u00e9 \u00e0 lancer des tablettes haut de gamme comme la [Surface Pro 3](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Surface) ou la [Surface Pro 4](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Surface), ainsi que des t\u00e9l\u00e9phones comme les [Microsoft Lumia](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Lumia) [950](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Lumia_950) et [950 XL](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Lumia_950_XL&action=edit&redlink=1) [(en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Lumia_950_XL).\nEn mai [2017](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017), alors que Microsoft et ses concurrents ([Amazon](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon), [Apple](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple), [Google](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google) et [IBM](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM) notamment) s'appr\u00eatent \u00e0 int\u00e9grer un peu plus l'intelligence artificielle dans la vie courante, Satya Nadella a d\u00e9clar\u00e9 lors d'une conf\u00e9rence de presse que les d\u00e9veloppeurs ont la responsabilit\u00e9 d'emp\u00eacher un avenir [dystopique](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dystopique) de type 1984 de\n[George Orwell](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Orwell)ou du meilleur des mondes de\n[Aldous Huxley](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aldous_Huxley)(sans citer\n[Skynet](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skynet_(Terminator))). \u00c0 cette occasion Jason Wong, directeur de la recherche sur le design et le d\u00e9veloppement d'applications chez\n[Gartner](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gartner)lui a demand\u00e9 ce qu'il adviendra de ceux des emplois peu qualifi\u00e9s et de\nqui seront remplac\u00e9s par des robots\n[cols bleus](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Col_bleu_(classe_sociale)). D'autres craignent que l'intelligence artificielle capte \u00e9galement un jour prochain une part croissante du travail des\n[[24]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-24); sujet abord\u00e9 dans les d\u00e9bats du\n[cols blancs](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Col_blanc_(classe_sociale))[Forum \u00e9conomique mondial](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forum_%C3%A9conomique_mondial)de\n[Davos](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davos)en\n.\n[[25]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-25)En 2024, sa r\u00e9mun\u00e9ration comme dirigeant de Microsoft s'\u00e9l\u00e8ve \u00e0 79,1 millions de dollars, en hausse de 63% par rapport \u00e0 2023 [26]. Une somme essentiellement compos\u00e9e d'actions (pour une valeur d'environ 71 millions de dollars).\nVie priv\u00e9e\n[[modifier](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&veaction=edit\u00a7ion=7)|\n[modifier le code](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&action=edit\u00a7ion=7)]\nSatya Nadella est mari\u00e9 depuis 1992 \u00e0 Anupama Priyadarshini [27], une architecte de formation\n. Le couple a trois enfants, deux filles et un fils. En 2022, Satya et Anupama Nadella perdent leur fils Zain, qui meurt \u00e0 l'\u00e2ge de 26 ans et qui souffrait de\n[[7]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-NadellaFamily-7)[paralysie c\u00e9r\u00e9brale](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paralysie_c%C3%A9r%C3%A9brale)\n[[7]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-NadellaFamily-7),\n.\n[[28]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-28)Prix et distinctions\n[[modifier](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&veaction=edit\u00a7ion=8)|\n[modifier le code](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&action=edit\u00a7ion=8)]\nEn 2018, il est class\u00e9 par le [ Time Magazine](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_(magazine)) dans la liste des 100 personnes les plus influentes du monde, le\n[Time 100](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_100).\n[[29]](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_note-29)Notes et r\u00e9f\u00e9rences\n[[modifier](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&veaction=edit\u00a7ion=9)|\n[modifier le code](https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Satya_Nadella&action=edit\u00a7ion=9)]\n[\u2191](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_ref-1)(en) \u00ab[Who is Satya Nadella](https://www.business-standard.com/about/who-is-satya-nadella)\u00bb, sur business-standard.com (consult\u00e9 le )[\u2191](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_ref-2)(en) \u00ab[Satya Nadella, CEO, Microsoft](https://www.forbes.com/profile/satya-nadella/)\u00bb, sur forbes.com (consult\u00e9 le )[\u2191](https://fr.wikipedia.org#cite_ref-3)(en) Jagmohan S. Bhanver, Nadella: The Changing Face of Microsoft, Hachette India,   "text": "GitHub.
6 ans 10 mois.
Systems Engineer.
DaimlerChryslersept. 2002 - déc. 2006 · 4 ans 4 moisStuttgart Area, Germany.
    I designed and implemented control systems for various advanced driver assistance systems like Brake Assist Plus, Pre-Safe Break, and Active Parking Assist. Brake Assist Plus and Pre-Safe Break were marquee features of the 2005 S-Class (W221) and 2006 CL-Class (C216).
    New to the S-Class: the PRE-SAFE brake.
      The new PRE-SAFE® brake from Mercedes-Benz represents a further milestone in car safety. The only system of its kind in the world, it automatically brakes the car before an impending rear-end collision. As a result, the PRE-SAFE® brake, in collaboration with Brake Assist PLUS, is able to prevent the collision or significantly reduce the severity of the accident.
 Founder & CEO.
ToDoSoftjanv. 1998 - août 2002 · 4 ans 8 moisBerlin, Germany.
    In my first company, we developed insurance software for Windows helping insurance agents to calculate prices for various insurance products. We sold our software to more than 1,500 insurance agents in Germany and later also offered web hosting and online insurance calculation.
    Chief Executive Officer.
      Temps pleinnov. 2021 - aujourd’hui · 3 ans 9 mois.
              Everything new from GitHub Universe 2022.
    Chief Product Officer.
      août 2021 - nov. 2021 · 4 mois.
    Vice President, Strategic Programs.
      oct. 2018 - août 2021 · 2 ans 11 moisGreater Seattle Area.
              GitHub is now free for teams.
              Every developer and team can now get private repositories with unlimited collaborators at no cost with GitHub Free, and we reduced prices for some of our paid plans.
              npm is joining GitHub - The GitHub Blog.
              We're excited to announce that npm will be joining GitHub.
              GitHub Arctic Code Vault.
              The GitHub Arctic Code Vault is a data repository preserved in the Arctic World Archive (AWA), a very-long-term archival facility 250 meters deep in the perm...
          Afficher les 5 médias.
Board Member.
Spice AIsept. 2022 - aujourd’hui · 2 ans 11 mois.
Microsoft.
3 ans 7 moisRedmond, WA, USA.
    Principal Director of PM.
      mars 2018 - oct. 2018 · 8 mois.
              Microsoft closes its $7.5B purchase of code-sharing platform GitHub.
              After getting EU approval a week ago, today Microsoft’s acquisition of GitHub, the Git-based code sharing and collaboration service with 31 million developers, has officially closed. The Redmond, WA-based software behemoth first said it would acquire...
              Pull request successfully merged. Starting build….
              With the Microsoft acquisition of GitHub complete, Nat Friedman joins as CEO.
              Microsoft brings its Visual Studio App Center lifecycle management tool to GitHub.
              Microsoft is now partnering with GitHub to make Visual Studio App Center natively available in GitHub through the GitHub marketplace.
    Principal Group PM Manager.
      mars 2017 - mars 2018 · 1 an 1 mois.
              Meet Visual Studio App Center - the future of HockeyApp.
              HockeyApp is the best way to collect live crash reports, get feedback from your users, distribute your betas, and analyze your test coverage.
    Principal PM Manager.
      avr. 2015 - mars 2017 · 2 ans.
              After Microsoft acquired HockeyApp, I became the manager for the team of program managers. Our product portfolio included HockeyApp, Visual Studio App Center (the next generation of HockeyApp), Xamarin Test Cloud, CodePush, and Azure Notification Hubs. My team defined the vision and features for each product, works for design and development teams on the implementation, and engages with customers to create industry-leading DevOps solutions.
 Co-Founder & CEO.
HockeyApp / Bit Stadium GmbHmars 2011 - mars 2015 · 4 ans 1 moisStuttgart, Germany.
    HockeyApp is the best way to collect live crash reports, get feedback from your users, distribute your betas, recruit new testers, and analyze your test coverage. Launched in 2011, HockeyApp was one of the first DevOps solutions for Android, iOS, macOS, and Windows developers, and made mobile developers around the world more productive. I co-founded HockeyApp together with Andreas Linde, Stefan Haubold, and Michael Simmons, and led the company as the CEO until the acquisition through Microsoft in December 2014.
    Microsoft Acquires HockeyApp.
      As mobile, cloud, and DevOps continue to transform the application development landscape, we are bringing together the most complete set of tools and services for highly productive mobile-first, cloud-first development - from cross-platform mobile development tools in Visual Studio to Application Insights in Visual Studio Online.
      TechCrunch: Microsoft Buys HockeyApp.
      Apple has Test Flight, Twitter has Crashlytics, and now Microsoft has HockeyApp. The Windows Phone maker has made an acquisition to continue building out its mobile business, this time focusing on developers.
 Co-Founder & CEO.
Codenauts GmbHmars 2010 - mars 2015 · 5 ans 1 moisRégion de Stuttgart.
    Driven by customer obsession, great design, and high quality, we created mobile apps for Viacom International Media Networks Germany, Zattoo Inc, Dekra Automobil GmbH, and for YOC AG. Reference apps include the South Park app for iOS and Android, Zattoo for Android, or the original version of the Postbank app. As part of the HockeyApp acquisition, the Codenauts team joined Microsoft and now works on SDKs for HockeyApp and Visual Studio Mobile Center.
 Freelance Software Developer.
MTV Networks Germany GmbHavr. 2009 - févr. 2010 · 11 moisBerlin, Germany.
    I worked on GameOne, ClubNick, and other MTV properties, mostly as a backend developer using Ruby on Rails and JavaScript.
Project Manager.
Robert Bosch GmbHjanv. 2007 - déc. 2008 · 2 ansStuttgart Area, Germany.
    I managed the team of software developers for Side View Assist, the first ever ultrasonic-based system for monitoring the blind spot of cars and trucks.
      Bosch Side View Assist.
      Bosch is launching the new Side View Assist -- the world's first ultrasonic-based system for monitoring the blind spot.",

{
  "title": "GitHub - Wikipedia",
  "author": null,
  "hostname": "wikipedia.org",
  "date": "2008-07-22",
  "fingerprint": "2b44950947e64ac2",
  "id": null,
  "license": null,
  "comments": "",
  "text": "GitHub.
| Type of business |
|
|---|
[version control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Version_control)[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-1)[San Francisco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco), California, U.S.[Founder(s)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_founder)
[Tom Preston-Werner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Preston-Werner)[Chris Wanstrath](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Wanstrath)[P. J. Hyett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P._J._Hyett)- Scott Chacon.
- Mike Taylor (CFO)
- Kyle Daigle (COO)
- Collaborative.
[version control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Version_control)(GitHub) - AI development tools (
[GitHub Copilot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GitHub_Copilot)) [Web host](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_hosting_service)(GitHub Pages)[Package repository](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Package_repository)([npm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Npm))
[Revenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revenue)
[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-techcrunch.com-2)[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-3)[Parent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holding_company)
[Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft)(2018–present)[github](https://github.com/) .com[IPv6](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv6)support.
[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-4)[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-5)[Users](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Registered_user)
)[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit)[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-6)[ASN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_System_Number)
[36459](https://bgp.tools/as/36459)GitHub ([/ˈɡɪthʌb/](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English) ⓘ) is a.
[proprietary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proprietary_software)developer platform that allows developers to create, store, manage, and share their code. It uses.
[Git](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Git)to provide.
[distributed version control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_version_control)and GitHub itself provides.
[access control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Access_control),
[bug tracking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bug_tracking_system),
[software feature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_feature)requests,
[task management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Task_management),
[continuous integration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_integration), and.
[wikis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wiki)for every project.
Headquartered in.
[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-hugeinvestment-9)[California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California),
GitHub, Inc.has been a subsidiary of.
[Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft)since 2018.
[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-techcrunch-10)It is commonly used to host [open source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_source) software development projects. [11] As of January 2023,
GitHub reported having over 100 million developers and more than 420 million.
[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit)[repositories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Repository_(version_control)), including at least 28 million public repositories.
It is the world's largest.
[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-12)[source code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source_code)host as of June 2023.
Over five billion developer contributions were made to more than 500 million open source projects in 2024.
[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit)
[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-13)About.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=1)]
Founding.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=2)]
The development of the GitHub platform began on October 19, 2007. [14] The site was launched in April 2008 by.
[Tom Preston-Werner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Preston-Werner),
[Chris Wanstrath](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Wanstrath),
[P. J. Hyett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P._J._Hyett)and Scott Chacon after it had been available for a few months as a.
[beta release](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beta_release).
Its name was chosen as a compound of.
[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-pastie-15)and.
[Git](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Git)hub.
[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-16)Structure of the organization.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=3)]
GitHub, Inc. was originally a [flat organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flat_organization) with no middle managers, instead relying on [self-management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workers%27_self-management). [17] Employees could choose to work on projects that interested them (
[open allocation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_allocation)), but the chief executive set salaries.
[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-nyt-18)In 2014, the company added a layer of [middle management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_management) in response to harassment allegations against its co-founder and then-CEO, Thomas Preston-Werner, and his wife, Theresa Preston-Werner. As a result of the scandal, [Tom Preston-Werner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Preston-Werner) resigned from his position as CEO. [19] Co-founder and Product lead,
[Chris Wanstrath](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Wanstrath), became CEO.
[Julio Avalos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julio_Avalos), then General Counsel and Administrative Officer, assumed control over GitHub's business operations and day-to-day management.
[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-20)Finance.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=4)]
GitHub was a [bootstrapped](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entrepreneurship#Bootstrapping) [start-up business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Startup_company), which in its first years provided enough revenue to be funded solely by its three founders and start taking on employees.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-21)
In July 2012, four years after the company was founded, [Andreessen Horowitz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andreessen_Horowitz) invested $100 million in [venture capital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venture_capital) [9] with a $750 million valuation.
[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-22)In July 2015 GitHub raised another $250 million (~$314 million in 2023) of venture capital in a [series B round](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Series_B). The lead investor was [Sequoia Capital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequoia_Capital), and other investors were [Andreessen Horowitz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andreessen_Horowitz), [Thrive Capital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thrive_Capital), IVP (Institutional Venture Partners) and other venture capital funds.[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-23) [24] The company was then valued at approximately $2 billion.
[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-25)As of 2023, [update] GitHub was estimated to generate $1 billion in revenue annually.
[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-techcrunch.com-2)History.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=5)]
The GitHub service was developed by [Chris Wanstrath](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Wanstrath), [P. J. Hyett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P._J._Hyett), [Tom Preston-Werner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Preston-Werner), and Scott Chacon using [Ruby on Rails](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruby_on_Rails), and started in February 2008. [26] The company, GitHub, Inc., was formed in 2007 and is located in San Francisco.
[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-27)On February 24, 2009, GitHub announced that within the first year of being online, GitHub had accumulated over 46,000 public repositories, 17,000 of which were formed in the previous month. At that time, about 6,200 repositories had been [forked](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fork_(software_development)) at least once, and 4,600 had been merged.
That same year, the site was used by over 100,000 users, according to GitHub, [28] and had grown to host 90,000 unique public repositories, 12,000 having been forked at least once, for a total of 135,000 repositories.
[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-29)In 2010, GitHub was hosting 1 million repositories. [30] A year later, this number doubled.
[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-31)[ReadWriteWeb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ReadWriteWeb)reported that GitHub had surpassed.
[SourceForge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SourceForge)and.
[Google Code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Code)in total number of commits for the period of January to May 2011.
On January 16, 2013, GitHub passed the 3 million users mark and was then hosting more than 5 million repositories.
[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-32)By the end of the year, the number of repositories was twice as great, reaching 10 million repositories.
[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-33)
[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-34)In 2015, GitHub opened an office in Japan, its first outside of the U.S.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-35)
On February 28, 2018, GitHub fell victim to the third-largest [distributed denial-of-service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_denial-of-service) (DDoS) attack in history, with incoming traffic reaching a peak of about 1.35 terabits per second.[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-DDOS-36)
On June 19, 2018, GitHub expanded its GitHub Education by offering free education bundles to all schools.[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-37)[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-38)
On June 11, 2019, it was announced that former [Bitnami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitnami) chief operating officer (COO) and co-founder, Erica Brescia, would be GitHub's COO.[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-39)
On November 3, 2021, GitHub announced that CEO [Nat Friedman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nat_Friedman), who become CEO when Microsoft acquired GitHub, was stepping down as CEO and GitHub's chief product officer, Thomas Dohmke, would become CEO on November 15.[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-40)
On August 11, 2025 [Thomas Dohmke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Dohmke) announced that he was to step down as CEO at the end of 2025, to pursue entrepreneurial endeavors. Microsoft did not immediately share their intention to find a direct replacement.[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-41)
Acquisition by Microsoft.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=6)]
From 2012, [Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft) became a significant user of GitHub, using it to host open-source projects and development tools such as [.NET Core](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.NET), [Chakra Core](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chakra_(JavaScript_engine)), [MSBuild](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MSBuild), [PowerShell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PowerShell), [PowerToys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_PowerToys), [Visual Studio Code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Studio_Code), [Windows Calculator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Calculator), [Windows Terminal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Terminal) and the bulk of its product documentation (now to be found on [Microsoft Docs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Learn)).[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-venturebeat-43)[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-:1-44)
On June 4, 2018, Microsoft announced its intent to acquire GitHub for US$7.5 billion (~$8.96 billion in 2023). [45] The deal closed on October 26, 2018.
GitHub continued to operate independently as a community, platform and business.
[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-46)Under Microsoft, the service was led by.
[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-47)[Xamarin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xamarin)'s.
[Nat Friedman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nat_Friedman), reporting to.
[Scott Guthrie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Guthrie), executive vice president of Microsoft Cloud and AI.
[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-48)
[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-49)There have been concerns from developers Kyle Simpson, [JavaScript](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JavaScript) trainer and author, and Rafael Laguna, CEO at [Open-Xchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-Xchange) over Microsoft's purchase, citing uneasiness over Microsoft's handling of previous acquisitions, such as [Nokia's mobile business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Mobile) and [Skype](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skype).[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-50)[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-51)
This acquisition was in line with Microsoft's business strategy under CEO [Satya Nadella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satya_Nadella), which has seen a larger focus on [cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing) services, alongside the development of and contributions to open-source software.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-techcrunch-10)[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-:1-44)[[52]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-52) Harvard Business Review argued that Microsoft was intending to acquire GitHub to get access to its user base, so it can be used as a.
[loss leader](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loss_leader)to encourage the use of its other development products and services.
[[53]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-53)Concerns over the sale bolstered interest in competitors: [Bitbucket](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitbucket) (owned by [Atlassian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlassian)), [GitLab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GitLab) and [SourceForge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SourceForge) (owned by [Slashdot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slashdot)) reported that they had seen spikes in new users intending to migrate projects from GitHub to their respective services.[[54]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-atlassian-10reasons-54)[[55]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-zdnet-rivalsgain-55)[[56]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-56)[[57]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-57)[[58]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-58)
In September 2019, GitHub acquired [Semmle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semmle), a code analysis tool. [59] In February 2020, GitHub launched in India under the name GitHub India Private Limited.
In March 2020, GitHub announced that it was acquiring.
[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-60)[npm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Npm_(software)), a JavaScript packaging vendor, for an undisclosed sum of money.
The deal was closed on April 15, 2020.
[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-61)
[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-62)In early July 2020, the GitHub Archive Program was established to archive its open-source code in perpetuity.[[63]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-blog-63)
Mascot.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=7)]
GitHub's [mascot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mascot) is Mona, [64] an.
[anthropomorphized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropomorphized)"octocat" with five.
[octopus-like arms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cephalopod_limb).
[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Octodex_FAQ-65)The character was created by graphic designer.
[[66]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Jaramillo-66)[Simon Oxley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Oxley)as.
[clip art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clip_art)to sell on.
[iStock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IStock),
a website that enables designers to market.
[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-DeAmicis-67)[royalty-free](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royalty-free)
[digital images](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_image). The illustration GitHub chose was a character that Oxley had named Octopuss.
Since GitHub wanted Octopuss for their logo (a use that the iStock license disallows), they negotiated with Oxley to buy exclusive rights to the image.
[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-DeAmicis-67)
[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-DeAmicis-67)GitHub renamed Octopuss to Octocat, [67] and trademarked the character along with the new name.
Later, GitHub hired illustrator Cameron McEfee to adapt Octocat for different purposes on the website and promotional materials; McEfee and various GitHub users have since created hundreds of variations of the character, which are available on.
[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Octodex_FAQ-65)[The Octodex](https://octodex.github.com/).
[[68]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-McEfee-68)
[[69]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-69)Services.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=8)]
Projects on GitHub can be accessed and managed using the standard [Git](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Git) command-line interface; all standard Git commands work with it. GitHub also allows users to browse public [repositories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content_repository) on the site. Multiple desktop clients and Git [plugins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plug-in_(computing)) are also available. In addition, the site provides [social networking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking)-like functions such as feeds, followers, wikis (using [wiki software](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wiki_software) called [Gollum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gollum_Wiki)), and a [social network graph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaboration_graph) to display how developers work on their versions ("[forks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fork_(software_development))") of a repository and what fork (and branch within that fork) is newest.
Anyone can browse and download public repositories, but only registered users can contribute content to repositories. With a registered user account, users can have discussions, manage repositories, submit contributions to others' repositories, and [review changes to code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Code_review). GitHub began offering limited private repositories at no cost in January 2019 (limited to three contributors per project). Previously, only public repositories were free.[[70]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-70)[[71]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-71) [72] On April 14, 2020, GitHub made "all of the core GitHub features" free for everyone, including "private repositories with unlimited collaborators."
[[73]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-73)The fundamental software that underpins GitHub is [Git](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Git) itself, written by [Linus Torvalds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linus_Torvalds), creator of Linux. The additional software that provides the GitHub user interface was written using [Ruby on Rails](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruby_on_Rails) and [Erlang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erlang_(programming_language)) by GitHub, Inc. developers Wanstrath, [74] Hyett, and Preston-Werner.
Scope.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=9)]
The primary purpose of GitHub is to facilitate the [version control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Version_control) and [issue tracking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Issue_tracking_system) aspects of software development. Labels, milestones, responsibility assignment, and a search engine are available for issue tracking. For version control, Git (and, by extension, GitHub) allows [pull requests](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pull_request) to propose changes to the source code. Users who can review the proposed changes can see a diff between the requested changes and approve them. In Git terminology, this action is called "committing" and one instance of it is a "commit." A history of all commits is kept and can be viewed at a later time.
In addition, GitHub supports the following formats and features:
- Documentation,
including automatically rendered[[75]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-75)[README](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/README)files in a variety of[Markdown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markdown)-like file formats (see[README § On GitHub](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/README#On_GitHub)) [Wikis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikis),with some repositories consisting solely of wiki content. These include curated lists of recommended software which have become known as awesome lists.[[76]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-76)[[77]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-77)[[78]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-78)[GitHub Codespaces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GitHub_Codespaces), an[online IDE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_IDE)providing users with a virtual machine intended to be a work environment to build and test code[[79]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-79)[[80]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-80)[[81]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-81)- Graphs: pulse, contributors, commits, code frequency, punch card, network, members.
- Integrations Directory.
[[82]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-82) - Email notifications.
[[83]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-83) - Discussions.
[[84]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-84) - Option to subscribe someone to notifications by.
[@ mentioning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mention_(blogging))them.[[85]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-85) [Emojis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emoji)[[86]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-86)- Nested.
[task-lists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/To_do_list)within files - Visualization of.
[geospatial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geospatial_analysis)data - 3D render files can be previewed using an integrated STL file viewer that displays the files on a "3D canvas."
The viewer is powered by[[87]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-3d-87)[WebGL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WebGL)and[Three.js](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three.js). - Support for previewing many common image formats, including Photoshop's PSD files.
- PDF document viewer.
- Security Alerts of known.
[Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Vulnerabilities_and_Exposures)in different packages.
GitHub's Terms of Service do not require public software projects hosted on GitHub to meet the [Open Source Definition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Source_Definition). The [terms of service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terms_of_service) state, "By setting your repositories to be viewed publicly, you agree to allow others to view and fork your repositories."[[88]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-88)
GitHub Enterprise.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=10)]
GitHub Enterprise is a self-managed version of GitHub with similar functionality. It can be run on an organization's hardware or a cloud provider and has been available as of November 2011.[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit) [89] In November 2020, source code for GitHub Enterprise Server was leaked online in an apparent protest against DMCA takedown of.
[youtube-dl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youtube-dl). According to GitHub, the source code came from GitHub accidentally sharing the code with Enterprise customers themselves, not from an attack on GitHub servers.
[[90]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-90)
[[91]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-91)GitHub Pages.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=11)]
In 2008, GitHub introduced GitHub Pages, a [static](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Static_web_page) [web hosting service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_hosting_service) for [blogs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blog), project documentation,[[92]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-92) [93] and books.
All GitHub Pages content is stored in a Git repository as files served to visitors verbatim or in.
[[94]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-94)[Markdown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GitHub_Flavored_Markdown)format. GitHub is integrated with.
[Jekyll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jekyll_(software))static website and blog generator and GitHub continuous integration pipelines. Each time the content source is updated, Jekyll regenerates the website and automatically serves it via GitHub Pages infrastructure.
[[95]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-95)Like the rest of GitHub, it includes free and paid service tiers. Websites generated through this service are hosted either as [subdomains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subdomain) of the github.io domain or can be connected to custom [domains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_name) bought through a third-party [domain name registrar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_name_registrar). [96] GitHub Pages supports HTTPS encryption.
[[97]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-97)
[[98]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-98)GitHub Actions.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=12)]
GitHub Actions was officially launched on November 13, 2019. It was first announced in October 2018 at GitHub Universe as a way to automate workflows, but the full general availability (GA) release came a year later in 2019. GitHub Actions, [99] which allows building.
[continuous integration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_integration)and.
[continuous deployment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_deployment)pipelines for testing, releasing and deploying software without the use of third-party websites/platforms. Unlike many other CI/CD tools, GitHub Actions launched with a marketplace where developers could share and reuse prebuilt actions (e.g., testing, linting, deployments). GitHub wanted to reduce reliance on third-party services and keep developers within the GitHub ecosystem. GitHub Actions provided hosted runners (Linux, Windows, macOS) that could dynamically scale, eliminating the need for self-managed build servers.
Gist.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=13)]
GitHub also operates a [pastebin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pastebin)-style site called Gist, which is for [code snippets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snippet_(programming)), as opposed to GitHub proper, which is usually used for larger projects. [15] Tom Preston-Werner débuted the feature at a Ruby conference in 2008.
[[100]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-100)Gist builds on the traditional simple concept of a [pastebin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pastebin) by adding version control for code snippets, easy forking, and [TLS encryption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_Layer_Security) for private pastes. Because each "gist" is its own Git repository, multiple code snippets can be contained in a single page, and they can be pushed and pulled using Git.[[101]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-101)
Unregistered users could upload Gists until March 19, 2018, when uploading Gists was restricted to logged-in users, reportedly to mitigate [spamming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spamming) on the page of recent Gists.[[102]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-102)
Gists' [URLs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/URL) use hexadecimal IDs, and edits to Gists are recorded in a [revision history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Version_control), which can show the text difference of thirty revisions per page with an option between a "split" and "unified" view. Like repositories, Gists can be forked, "starred", i.e., publicly bookmarked, and commented on. The count of revisions, stars, and forks is indicated on the gist page.[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-103)
Education program.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=14)]
GitHub launched a new program called the GitHub Student Developer Pack to give students free access to more than a dozen popular development tools and services. GitHub partnered with [Bitnami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitnami), [Crowdflower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crowdflower), [DigitalOcean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DigitalOcean), DNSimple, [HackHands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HackHands), [Namecheap](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Namecheap), Orchestrate, Screenhero, [SendGrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SendGrid), [Stripe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stripe_(company)), [Travis CI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travis_CI), and [Unreal Engine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unreal_Engine) to launch the program.[[104]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-104)
In 2016, GitHub announced the launch of the GitHub Campus Experts program [105] to train and encourage students to grow technology communities at their universities. The Campus Experts program is open to university students 18 years and older worldwide.
GitHub Campus Experts are one of the primary ways that GitHub funds student-oriented events and communities, Campus Experts are given access to training, funding, and additional resources to run events and grow their communities. To become a Campus Expert, applicants must complete an online training course with multiple modules to develop community leadership skills.
[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-106)GitHub Marketplace service.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=15)]
GitHub also provides some [software as a service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_as_a_service) (SaaS) integrations for adding extra features to projects. Those services include:
- Waffle.io: project management for software teams, which allows users to automatically see pull requests, automated builds, reviews, and deployments across repositories.
[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-107) - Rollbar: provides real-time debugging tools and full-stack exception reporting.
[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-108)[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-109) - Codebeat: automated code analysis for web and mobile developers.
[][citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed) [Travis CI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travis_CI):[continuous integration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_integration)service.[][citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)- GitLocalize: provides utilities to manage project translation and internationalisation.
[][citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
GitHub Sponsors.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=16)]
GitHub Sponsors allows users to make monthly money donations to projects hosted on GitHub. [110] The public beta was announced on May 23, 2019, and the project accepts waitlist registrations.
[The Verge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Verge)said that GitHub Sponsors "works exactly like.
[Patreon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patreon)" because "developers can offer various funding tiers that come with different perks, and they'll receive recurring payments from supporters who want to access them and encourage their work" except with "zero fees to use the program." Furthermore, GitHub offers incentives for early adopters during the first year: it pledges to cover payment processing costs and match sponsorship payments up to $5,000 per developer. Furthermore, users can still use similar services like Patreon and Open Collective and link to their websites.
[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-111)
[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-112)GitHub Copilot.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=17)]
GitHub Copilot was one of the first widely adopted [AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI)-assisted software development tools. The preview launched in 2021 for [VSCode](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VSCode) users and was based on [Open AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_AI)'s Codex model.
GitHub Copilot is now available to use on GitHub.com directly, on the [command line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Command_line), as well as in several [IDEs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_development_environment). Users are able to choose from a range of [LLMs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LLM) for some features.
GitHub Archive Program.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=18)]
In July 2020, GitHub stored a February archive of the site [63] in an abandoned mountain mine in.
[Svalbard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Svalbard), Norway, part of the.
[Arctic World Archive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arctic_World_Archive)and not far from the.
[Svalbard Global Seed Vault](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Svalbard_Global_Seed_Vault). The archive contained the code of all active public repositories, as well as that of dormant but significant public repositories. The 21.
[TB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terabyte)of data was stored on.
piqlFilmarchival film reels as.
[matrix (2D) barcode](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barcode#Matrix_(2D)_barcodes)(
[Boxing barcode](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boxing_barcode)), and is expected to last 500–1,000 years.
[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-113)
[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-114)
[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-115)
[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-buried-116)The GitHub Archive Program is also working with partners on Project Silica, in an attempt to store all public repositories for 10,000 years. It aims to write archives into the molecular structure of [quartz glass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quartz_glass) platters, using a high-precision [petahertz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petahertz) pulse laser, i.e. one that pulses a [quadrillion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadrillion) (1,000,000,000,000,000) times per second.[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-buried-116)
Controversies.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=19)]
Harassment allegations.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=20)]
In March 2014, GitHub programmer Julie Ann Horvath alleged that founder and CEO Tom Preston-Werner engaged in a pattern of [harassment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harassment) against her that led to her leaving the company. [117] In April 2014, GitHub released a statement denying Horvath's allegations.
[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-118)
[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-NYTResigns-119)However, following an internal investigation, GitHub confirmed the claims. GitHub's CEO Chris Wanstrath wrote on the company blog, "The investigation found Tom Preston-Werner in his capacity as GitHub's CEO acted inappropriately, including confrontational conduct, disregard of workplace complaints, insensitivity to the impact of his spouse's presence in the workplace, and failure to enforce an agreement that his spouse should not work in the office."
[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-120)Preston-Werner subsequently resigned from the company.
[[121]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Follow_up_to_the_investigation_results-121)The firm then announced it would implement new initiatives and trainings "to make sure employee concerns and conflicts are taken seriously and dealt with appropriately."
[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-:0-122)
[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-:0-122)Sanctions.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=21)]
On July 25, 2019, a developer based in Iran wrote on [Medium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medium_(website)) that GitHub had blocked his private repositories and prohibited access to GitHub pages. [123] Soon after, GitHub confirmed that it was now blocking developers in.
[Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran),
[Crimea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimea),
[Cuba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuba),
[North Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Korea), and.
[Syria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syria)from accessing private repositories.
However, GitHub reopened access to GitHub Pages days later, for public repositories regardless of location. It was also revealed that using GitHub while visiting sanctioned countries could result in similar actions occurring on a user's account. GitHub responded to complaints and the media through a spokesperson, saying:
[[124]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-124)GitHub is subject to US trade control laws, and is committed to full compliance with applicable law. At the same time, GitHub's vision is to be the global platform for.
[developer]collaboration, no matter where developers reside. As a result, we take seriously our responsibility to examine government mandates thoroughly to be certain that users and customers are not impacted beyond what is required by law. This includes keeping public repositories services, including those for open source projects, available and accessible to support personal communications involving developers in sanctioned regions.[[125]][[126]]
Developers who feel that they should not have restrictions can appeal for the removal of said restrictions, including those who only travel to, and do not reside in, those countries. GitHub has forbidden the use of [VPNs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_private_network) and [IP proxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proxy_server) to access the site from sanctioned countries, as purchase history and IP addresses are how they flag users, among other sources.[[127]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-127)
Censorship.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=22)]
On December 4, 2014, Russia blacklisted GitHub.com because GitHub initially refused to take down user-posted suicide manuals. [128] After a day, Russia withdrew its block,
and GitHub began blocking specific content and pages in Russia.
[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-129)On December 31, 2014, India blocked GitHub.com along with 31 other websites over pro-
[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-130)[ISIS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISIS)content posted by users;
the block was lifted three days later.
[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-131)On October 8, 2016, Turkey blocked GitHub to prevent email leakage of a hacked account belonging to the country's energy minister.
[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-132)
[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-133)On March 26, 2015, a large-scale [DDoS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DDoS) attack was launched against GitHub.com that lasted for just under five days. [134] The attack, which appeared to originate from China, primarily targeted GitHub-hosted user content describing methods of.
[circumventing Internet censorship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_censorship_circumvention).
[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-135)
[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-136)
[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-137)On April 19, 2020, Chinese police detained Chen Mei and Cai Wei (volunteers for Terminus 2049, a project hosted on GitHub), and accused them of "picking quarrels and provoking trouble." Cai and Chen archived news articles, interviews, and other materials published on Chinese media outlets and social media platforms that have been removed by censors in China.[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-138)
ICE contract.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=23)]
GitHub has a $200,000 contract with [U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Immigration_and_Customs_Enforcement) (ICE) for the use of their on-site product GitHub Enterprise Server. This contract was renewed in 2019, despite internal opposition from many GitHub employees. In an email sent to employees, later posted to the GitHub blog on October 9, 2019, CEO [Nat Friedman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nat_Friedman) stated, "The revenue from the purchase is less than $200,000 and not financially material for our company." He announced that GitHub had pledged to donate $500,000 to "nonprofit groups supporting immigrant communities targeted by [the current administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_presidency_of_Donald_Trump)." [139] In response, at least 150 GitHub employees signed an open letter re-stating their opposition to the contract, and denouncing alleged human rights abuses by ICE. As of November 13, 2019,
five workers had resigned over the contract.
[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit)
[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-140)
[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-141)
[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-142)The ICE contract dispute came into focus again in June 2020 due to the company's decision [to abandon "master/slave" branch terminology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master%E2%80%93slave_(technology)#Controversy), spurred by the George Floyd protests and [Black Lives Matter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Lives_Matter) movement. [143] Detractors of GitHub describe the branch renaming to be a form of.
[performative activism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Performative_activism)and have urged GitHub to cancel their ICE contract instead.
An open letter from members of the open source community was shared on GitHub in December 2019, demanding that the company drop its contract with ICE and provide more transparency into how they conduct business and partnerships. The letter has been signed by more than 700 people.
[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-144)
[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-145)Capitol riot comments and employee firing.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=24)]
In January 2021, GitHub fired one of its employees after he expressed concern for colleagues following the [January 6 United States Capitol attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack), calling some of the rioters "[Nazis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neo-Nazism)". [146] After an investigation, GitHub's COO said there were "significant errors of judgment and procedure" with the company's decision to fire the employee. As a result of the investigation, GitHub reached out to the employee, and the company's head of human resources resigned.
[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-147)
[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-148)Twitter source code leak.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=25)]
In 2023, parts of the social media platform [Twitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter) were uploaded onto GitHub. The leak was first reported by the New York Times and was part of a legal filing Twitter submitted to the [United States District Court for the Northern District of California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_Northern_District_of_California). Twitter claimed that the postings infringed on copyright property owned by them, and asked the court for information to identify the user who posted the source code to GitHub, under the username "FreeSpeechEnthusiast".[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-149)
Reception.
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GitHub&action=edit§ion=26)]
In 2012, [Linus Torvalds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linus_Torvalds), the original developer of Git, highly praised GitHub, stating, "The hosting of github [ sic] is excellent. They've done a good job on that. I think GitHub should be commended enormously for making open source project hosting so easy." However, he also sharply criticized the implementation of GitHub's merging interface, saying, "Git comes with a nice pull-request generation module, but GitHub instead decided to replace it with their own totally inferior version. As a result, I consider GitHub useless for these kinds of things. It's fine for hosting, but the pull requests and the online commit editing, are just pure garbage."
[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-150)
